Detailed Analysis:
The telescoping computation S(x) = ∑_{k=0}^{n−1} H(x + k/n) = f(x+1) − f(x) is fine algebraically, but the proof then makes a crucial incorrect deduction: “since f(0) = f(1), by continuity on [0,1], it follows that f(x+1) = f(x) for x in [0,1].” Equality at the endpoints does not imply periodicity; thus asserting S(x) = 0 for all x is a logic violation. Moreover, H(x) = f(x+1/n) − f(x) is not defined on all of [0,1] unless one handles boundary issues (restricting domain to [0, 1−1/n] or giving a precise periodic extension). The talk of “gluing the interval” or using “mod 1” is a hidden assumption and presented vaguely without formal construction. Because the claim that the sum is zero for all x is invalid, the subsequent contradiction argument about H having constant sign does not go through. A standard fix is to define g(x) = f(x) − f(x+1/n) on [0, 1−1/n]; if g has constant sign, chaining inequalities along x, x+1/n, …, x+1 leads to f(0) ≠ f(1), contradicting the hypothesis, so g must vanish somewhere.

Analysis:
The student correctly identifies the target probability p and gives a valid computation of P(A < B) for independent uniforms on intervals [0, 1+a] and [0, 1+b] via an area argument in the unit square. However, the core requirement—to construct explicit independent random variables X1,…,Xn (or explicit parameters a1,…,an) so that for each k the probability P(X_{k-1} < X_k) equals the given p and the cycle closes with X0 = Xn—is not carried out. The text merely asserts that a “classical approach” or “trigonometric identities” ensure one can “walk around” and close the cycle, without supplying the recurrence, verifying closure after n steps, or showing that the specified p indeed results from the construction. The alternative “shifted-binomial” approach is likewise only mentioned without details.

Thus the proof is vague and incomplete: it relies on unstated or unproven facts (“the factor involving cos² ensures closure,” “known closed-form” for probabilities of shifted binomials) and does not actually produce the required random variables. This constitutes an invalid construction (no actual construction provided), hidden assumptions (existence of a cyclic sequence satisfying the constraints), and an incomplete proof. There is no apparent logic violation or incorrect case split in the unit-square computation.
